comment_text: You could've mentioned in the last part that in fact the matrices BA + CA are not defined, as B and C are (m x n) and A is (k x m) matrix; n =/= k, so you can't even do that multiplication. But if you assume equal dimensions (like 'square' matrices), it could be helpful to know they are distributive as well, I suppose..
i can see how this can be a boring, maybe trivial, but necessary part of a solid grounding to more complex formulations of linear algebra
